Description: Mould-made scarab, possibly in Egyptian blue; detailed back with well modelled clypeus, prothorax marked with double line, elytra with single line, and triangle at junction; legs feathered at front and well-modelled at side; flattened profile of back; underside bearing finely incised motif representing lion walking to right with head looking forward and tail held high, sun-disc above back and Maat feather in front; pierced lengthways; blue paste (?) now completely bleached out; smooth and hard core.
Curator's comments: Scarabs with a lion motif depicted on the base belong to a standard group produced at the “Scarab Factory” (on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming). Petrie illustrated a number of different versions (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, 34-45 and 146 for this example). This lion displays an hellenizing style (elongated body and elegant shape). The scarab belongs to a type which was widely distributed in Sardinia, south Italy, Carthage, Perachora and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 127-128, type XXXV, subtype 1-7, see especially 5 for this piece). See Sydney, The Nicholson Museum NM00.128.11 for a lion depicted in a similar style. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.) forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum, 16th –17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 146)
Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 127-128, type XXXV 5)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OE.08) (phase 3)
